com.fraudpointer.api.clients
Class Client

java.lang.Object
  com.fraudpointer.api.clients.Client
All Implemented Interfaces:
IClient
public class Client
extends java.lang.Object
implements IClient

This is a class that implements IClient interface.

You can safely use this implementation and avoid writing everything from scratch.

Serializing objects using the json format.

Since Fraudpointer Server offers a RESTful JSON API, we had to find a way to serialize and deserialize our java class instances to this particular format. Google GSON library does the magic pretty well and this is what we have used.

Consuming RESTful web services

Consuming the RESTful web services of Fraudpointer, is a piece of case when you use a library like jersey.

Method Detail

createAssessmentSession

public AssessmentSession createAssessmentSession()
                                          throws ClientException
Description copied from interface: IClient
Communicates with FraudPointer Server and gets back a ready to use AssessmentSession object.This is the first method that you should call.

It should be used as soon as you want to start using the FraudPointer service. Without an AssessmentSession object you cannot do anything.

Specified by:
createAssessmentSession in interface IClient
Returns:
An object of type AssessmentSession as returned by FraudPointer Server. Object should contain the AssessmentSession.id that uniquely identifies this AssessmentSession. You should use this AssessmentSession.id in whichever place the AssessmentSession id is required.

Method always returns a valid object, unless an exception is thrown.
Throws:
ClientException - It may throw an ClientException if an error occurs

appendEventToAssessmentSession

public Event appendEventToAssessmentSession(AssessmentSession assessmentSession,
                                            Event paramEvent)
                                     throws ClientException
Description copied from interface: IClient
Appends an Event to an AssessmentSession object.

This method also communicates with the FraudPointer Server, which will store all Event data alongside with the AssessmentSession given.

You can call this method as many times as you want (as long as you pass a new Event on each call). It is actually recommended to do so. In other words, it is recommended to create various Events, of various types and send them to FraudPointer to be stored against an AssessmentSession.

Specified by:
appendEventToAssessmentSession in interface IClient
Parameters:
assessmentSession - Should be constructed with a call to createAssessmentSession()
paramEvent - Should be constructed with a call to new Event(event_type)
Returns:
An object of type Event as returned by the FraudPointer Server.

Method always returns a valid object, unless an exception is thrown.
Throws:
ClientException - It may throw a ClientException if an error occurs

createFraudAssessment

public FraudAssessment createFraudAssessment(AssessmentSession assessmentSession,
                                             boolean interim)
                                      throws ClientException
Description copied from interface: IClient
This method should be called in order to evaluate the fraud level of an AssessmentSession.

This method should be called after having sent to FraudPointer Server one or more Events. It is used to evaluate the fraud risk of the AssessmentSession. Note that you can ask multiple interim Fraud Assessments, but you can only ask for one final (non-interim) Fraud Assessment. Interim Fraud Assessments can be requested in a cycle of interactions with the FraudPointer Server such as the following:

  • create assessment session
  • create event
  • add data to event
  • add data to event
  • ...
  • add data to event
  • append event to assessment session
  • create another event
  • add data to new event
  • add data to new event
  • ...
  • add data to new event
  • append new event to assessment session
  • create interim fraud assessment
  • create one more event
  • add data to last created event
  • add data to last created event
  • ...
  • add data to last created event
  • append last created event to assessment session
  • create interim fraud assessment
  • ....
  • create final (non
  • interim) fraud assessment

The last and only final (non-interim) fraud assessment will also create a CASE in FraudPointer Application.

Specified by:
createFraudAssessment in interface IClient
Parameters:
assessmentSession - A valid AssessmentSession, previously created with createAssessmentSession()
interim - A boolean value true or false. If true, then an interim FraudAssessment will be created. If false, a final (non-interim) FraudAssessment will be created
Returns:
A FraudAssessment valid object filled in with information returned by FraudPointer Server. It contains the Fraud Assessment Result.
Throws:
ClientException - It may throw a ClientException if an error occurs

getFraudAssessment

public FraudAssessment getFraudAssessment(AssessmentSession assessmentSession,
                                          java.lang.String assessmentId)
                                   throws ClientException
Description copied from interface: IClient
Gets the results of a previously assessed session.

Use this method to retrieve a previously created Fraud assessment. When you create a fraud assessment with createFraudAssessment you receive the result of the assessment and its Id. Using the session id and the assessment id you can retrieve that result with this method.

Specified by:
getFraudAssessment in interface IClient
Parameters:
assessmentSession - A valid AssessmentSession, previously created with createAssessmentSession()
assessmentId - A valid assessment id previously obtained with createFraudAssessment()
Returns:
A FraudAssessment valid object filled in with information that is related to this Fraud Assessment like Profile and Case
Throws:
ClientException - It may throw a ClientException if an error occurs

creditCardHash

public java.lang.String creditCardHash(java.lang.String creditCardNumber)
                                throws ClientException
Description copied from interface: IClient
Use this method to generate a hash of a credit card number. Use the generated hash to send the encrypted credit card number to FraudPointer Server instead of the credit card number itself.

FraudPointer Server tries to identify the existence of the same credit card number in various transactions. These transactions either take place during the same session or take place in different sessions, but at the same time, or took place in a session in the past. However, FraudPointer Server does not want to store the credit card numbers in clear format and it does not need to do that in order to accomplish its goal. Hence, you need to encrypt them using the method provided here. Note that hash is one-way encryption method and FraudPointer Server cannot derive the credit card number from the hash.
This method does not communicate with the FraudPointer Server to generate the hash. Works locally.

Also, note that there is a sample console application that only encrypts a credit card. The class is called EncryptCreditCard and you can see the code here: EncryptCreditCard. You can quickly run this utility from the command line with the following command too:

java -cp fraudpointer_client.jar com.fraudpointer.EncryptCreditCard

and it will print for you the string that will be sent to Fraudpointer server if that particular card is used in a transaction.

Specified by:
creditCardHash in interface IClient
Parameters:
creditCardNumber - The credit card number that you want to get its hash value.
Returns:
The hash of the credit card number. Note that if an empty string is returned, then something has gone wrong during the encryption. in that case, method throws a ClientException.
Throws:
ClientException
